articles.author: Abhishek Desikan
articles.description:
When I started writing code, I thought the goal was perfection.
A flawless feature. A zero-bug release. The cleanest, DRYest, most elegant solution to every problem.
But if there‚Äôs one thing software engineering teaches you‚Äîagain and again‚Äîit‚Äôs this: Perfect doesn‚Äôt ship. Progress does.
Behind every product you love, every app you use daily, and every "it-just-works" moment, there‚Äôs a messy history of trade-offs, iterations, rewrites, and late-night breakthroughs. There‚Äôs never been a perfect version‚Äîonly the best version for right now.
‚ÄúIf you‚Äôre aiming for perfection, you‚Äôll never release,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúBut if you aim for learning, you‚Äôll improve with every commit.‚Äù
That‚Äôs the shift that happens when you grow‚Äînot just as a coder, but as an engineer.
Early Career: Learning the Rules
Most engineers begin their journey by learning the rules.
Mid-Career: Building Beyond Code
As you gain experience, your job evolves. You're not just writing functions‚Äîyou‚Äôre:
The Myth of Mastery
There‚Äôs a moment many engineers hit mid-career: you expect to feel confident, but instead, you feel behind.
Late Career: Scaling Impact
By the time you‚Äôre a senior or staff engineer, the problems you solve are rarely just technical.
Letting Go to Grow
So what does it really mean to grow as a software engineer?
Final Thoughts: We‚Äôre All Still Learning
No matter where you are in your career‚Äîjust starting out, mid-level and unsure, or senior and scaling‚Äîremember this:
You don‚Äôt have to be perfect. You just have to keep learning.
Great software is built by people who care enough to try, fail, ask, share, and try again.
People like Abhishek Desikan, who show that engineering is not just about building products‚Äîit‚Äôs about building people, teams, and ethical systems that serve others well.
‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not just writing code,‚Äù Desikan reminds us. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre writing the story of how people experience technology.‚Äù
And when we do that with care‚Äîeven if it‚Äôs not perfect‚Äîwe‚Äôre already doing something right.
articles.title: Abhishek Desikan | Growing as a Software Engineer Means Letting Go of Perfection

Bitcoin (BTC) price is notoriously sensitive to global liquidity. Some analysts go as far as calling their correlation near-perfect, with a lag of about three months. This relationship is fueling the current bullish narrative as BTC price soars back above $100,000, but how long can this trend last?

articles.author: Cointelegraph by Naman Kabra
articles.description:
Opinion by: Naman Kabra, co-founder and CEO of NodeOps Network
Graphics Processing Units (GPUs) have become the default hardware for many AI workloads, especially when training large models. That thinking is everywhere. While it makes sense in some contexts, it's also created a blind spot that's holding us back.
GPUs have earned their reputation. They're incredible at crunching massive numbers in parallel, which makes them perfect for training large language models or running high-speed AI inference. That's why companies like OpenAI, Google, and Meta spend a lot of money building GPU clusters.
While GPUs may be preferred for running AI, we cannot forget about Central Processing Units (CPUs), which are still very capable. Forgetting this could be costing us time, money, and opportunity.
CPU‚Ä¶
articles.title: AI's GPU obsession blinds us to a cheaper, smarter solution
